author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Noted Palestinian Poet Released by Israel After Two-Day Detention
description: Mosab Abu Toha was detained by Israeli troops as his family was evacuating to southern Gaza. A number of other Palestinians detained under similar circumstances remain in custody.
content: A celebrated Palestinian poet and essayist who founded the Gaza Strip’s first English-language library was released by Israel on Tuesday, two days after he was detained as his family was fleeing to southern Gaza on foot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: David Letterman Reclaims His Desk at ‘The Late Show’
description: Eight years after retiring from the CBS show, the former late-night host sat down with his successor, Stephen Colbert.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five (Thanksgiving) Weeknight Dishes
description: White chicken chili to feed a crowd, super-scalable sheet-pan mushroom Parmigiana and no-chop chile crisp fettuccine Alfredo.
content: We’re on the cusp of Thanksgiving, and whether you’re making one dish or eight this week, you’ve got some work ahead of you. How can I help?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: High Winds Rattle Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Leading to Closures
description: Park administrators closed many roads and campgrounds during a busy week for visitors because of an increased risk of fire danger.
content: Roads and campgrounds in Great Smoky Mountains National Park were closed to visitors ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday as hurricane-force winds swept through eastern Tennessee, park administrators said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: The Beatles Are Still Charting the Future of Pop. It Looks Bleak.
description: Their latest song points toward a future where no golden goose need ever stop laying.
content: Earlier this month, alongside the arrival of a new Beatles single called “Now and Then,” there also came a 12 minute and 24 second promotional film — exactly three times as long as the song itself — explaining the project. Why so long a preface? Part of it was the solemnity of the occasion: This was, the film’s title card proclaimed, “the last Beatles song.” But there was another purpose, too, one that was uncomfortably hard to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Weeks and Ian Bradley
title: For Fall, Jackets and Knits With a Modern Edge
description: Well-defined lines and neutral tones give this season’s pieces a striking, pared-back look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches Rocket With Its First Spy Satellite
description: The country had failed to put such a satellite into orbit in its two previous attempts at such a launch. This time, it was getting help from Russia, according to South Korea.
content: North Korea launched a rocket on ​Tuesday in what South Korea​ said was an attempt to put its first military reconnaissance satellite in orbit, this time with technological help from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Early College Is the Equalizer We Need
description: The two free years of college are a boon to disadvantaged students.
content: I never got around to taking chemistry, and I missed the prom. It was because I was in college when I could have been in 11th and 12th grades. I was a student at Bard College at Simon’s Rock, an early college program in Great Barrington, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Nvidia Triples Quarterly Revenue, but Sales in China Are a Concern
description: Demand for the company’s A.I. chips remains high, but it said new U.S. export restrictions would hurt it sales to countries like China.
content: A start-up driving the artificial intelligence revolution may be in turmoil, but the semiconductor supplier propelling its innovations seems to be getting only stronger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sunita Sah
title: Speak Up at Thanksgiving. Your Health Depends on It.
description: Suppressing your opinions and emotions to keep the peace could come at the expense of your own physical and mental well-being.
content: The hum of conversation, the aroma of roasted turkey, the clinking of silverware on porcelain: This is how I remember last year’s Thanksgiving, spent at a dear friend’s home. I relished the inviting ambience until a conversation about the day’s cooking unexpectedly shifted to the topic of gender roles. It was then that my friend’s father, a revered patriarch in his mid-70s, wistfully mentioned how he missed the “good old days” when things were simpler and “people knew their place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Thanksgiving Travel Days Expected to Be Busiest in Nearly 20 Years
description: More people are expected to travel during the holiday weekend as airfare and gas prices drop. But rain and cold could pose obstacles through early Wednesday.
content: More holiday travelers will pack airports and highways this Thanksgiving as a drop in airfare and gas prices stokes the nation’s busiest travel time of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: A Rare Appearance for ‘Six Persimmons,’ a 13th-Century Masterpiece
description: An 800-year-old ink painting, regarded as the “Zen Mona Lisa,” has made a once-in-a-lifetime trip to the United States.
content: This may be your only chance to see “Six Persimmons.” Painted with ink on paper in the 13th century, probably by a Chinese monk named Muqi, as part of a handscroll that also included “Chestnuts,” it was acquired in the 1500s by a Japanese merchant; cut out of the scroll and mounted on sumptuous green-and-white fabric inlaid with golden peonies; and donated to Daitokuji Ryokoin Temple, the Zen Buddhist institution in Kyoto that has been its guardian ever since, displaying it to the public only once a year for a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Best Primer I’ve Heard on Israeli-Palestinian Peace Efforts
description: Aaron David Miller offers insights and lessons from decades of negotiating for peace in the Middle East.
content: It is too early to talk about a peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians. With the trauma of Oct. 7 still fresh for the Israeli public and with the ongoing devastation in Gaza, any talk of conflict-ending solutions is cruel fantasy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert and David Botti
title: Satellite Imagery Shows Ship Hijacked by Houthis Near Yemen Port
description: The vessel arrived Monday and was at anchor on Tuesday off the busy Red Sea port of Al-Hudaydah, according to an analysis of the imagery by The New York Times.
content: A vessel seized by Yemen’s Houthi militia in the Red Sea on Sunday was anchored just outside a busy Yemeni port on Tuesday, according to an analysis of satellite imagery by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: How Menopause Changes the Brain
description: Neurological changes and menopausal symptoms are linked to dementia for some. Here’s what to know.
content: Across the U.S., roughly 6 million adults 65 and over have Alzheimer’s disease. Almost two thirds of them are women — a discrepancy that researchers have long attributed to genetics and women’s longer life spans, among other reasons. But there is growing consensus that menopause may also be an important risk factor for the development of dementia later in life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Are You Grateful For?
description: Science shows that gratitude can improve your well-being. How easily does gratitude come to you?
content: Sunsets.Friendship.Your favorite teacher or coach.Your aunt’s pumpkin pie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Larissa Anderson and Daniel Ramirez
title: You, Too, Can Deep-Fry Your Turkey
description: The secret to (safely) frying your Thanksgiving bird.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’ Book Recommendations (2021)
description: Readings that the podcast’s guests say shaped their thinking.
content: “The Ezra Klein Show” explores ideas with some of today’s most dynamic thinkers. We cover politics, culture, history, philosophy, psychology, technology and more. The topics are wide-ranging, but every episode ends with Ezra asking his guest (or guests) to recommend a few books that have shaped their thinking. Below is a list of all the books recommended on the show in 2021, in reverse-chronological order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Wine Guide for a Changing World (for Better and for Worse)
description: Ray Isle’s “The World in a Wineglass” is a broad survey of vintners with a focus on sustainability and organic methods.
content: Winery owners appear to lead charmed lives. So, too, do wine writers and critics, if their small talk and Instagram feeds can be believed. A lot of chateaus, grand vistas, infinity pools, delicate stemware and candlelit dinners in private rooms seem to be involved. Wine people, for professional reasons, are frequently half-potted by 11 in the morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Choi
title: Jewels That Are Spiky, Squiggly and a Little Bit Wild
description: Leafy and serpentine designs give earrings, necklaces and other pieces an organic edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris and Jan Ransom
title: New York State Leans on Hospitals to Close Gaps in Social Safety Net
description: Amid a drumbeat of preventable errors by shelters, hospitals and care teams, state officials issued guidance to increase communication.
content: For years, the New York State Office of Mental Health has maintained a detailed database for sharing the psychiatric histories of people who rely on the social safety net — a tool that, when used correctly, can ensure the state’s most vulnerable people receive adequate care.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inclusion and Exclusion on Campus
description: Responses to a column by David Brooks. Also: A fuller Palestinian history; diversity at an Israeli hospital; preventing suicides; football in America.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Emily Flitter, Matthew Goldstein and Glenn Thrush
title: Binance Founder Pleads Guilty to Violating Money Laundering Rules
description: Changpeng Zhao will pay a $50 million fine and step down as chief executive of the company he created, the latest blow to the crypto world since the implosion of FTX last year.
content: Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the world, pleaded guilty to money laundering violations, the government said on Tuesday, a stunning blow to the most powerful and influential figure in the global crypto industry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Redefining the Role of First Lady in Ways That Still Resonate
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 21, 2023.
content: “Mrs. Carter revealed the hidden powers a first lady is bestowed and can use, should she choose to do so, that Americans had not seen since the days of Eleanor Roosevelt.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Rosner
title: Why Warblers Flock to Wealthier Neighborhoods
description: In the unequal distribution of birds and other species, ecologists are tracing the impact of bigoted urban policies adopted decades ago.
content: At a meeting of urban wildlife researchers in Washington, D.C., in June, one diagram made it into so many PowerPoint presentations that its recurrence became a running joke. The subject, though, was serious: The diagram illustrated the links between structural racism, pernicious landscape features such as urban heat islands, and impacts to biodiversity, and it came from a study published in the fall of 2020 in the journal Science.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’ Book Recommendations (2022)
description: Readings that the podcast’s guests say shaped their thinking.
content: “The Ezra Klein Show” explores ideas with some of today’s most dynamic thinkers. We cover politics, culture, history, philosophy, psychology, technology and more. The topics are wide-ranging, but every episode ends with Ezra asking his guest (or guests) to recommend a few books that have shaped their thinking. Below is a list of all the books recommended on the show in 2022, in reverse-chronological order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Families Fear for the Health of Ailing, Frail Israelis Held Hostage
description: Many of the more than 200 people seized by Hamas when it raided Israel had serious medical conditions. Some were badly injured in the attack. Doctors say they need medical care urgently.
content: When armed Hamas terrorists invaded her home on Oct. 7, Karina Engelbert was still recovering from a double mastectomy and breast reconstruction surgery that had gone terribly awry. She was weak and easily fatigued, and a buildup of painful scar tissue on her chest caused tightness, limiting her mobility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: From Land Mines to Drones, Tech Has Driven Fears About Autonomous Arms
description: Concern about weapons that can kill without a human decision is not entirely new.
content: Swarms of killer drones are likely to soon be a standard feature of battlefields around the world. That has ignited debate over how or whether to regulate their use and spurred concerns about the prospect of eventually turning life-or-death decisions over to artificial intelligence programs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Aaron David Miller
description: The Nov. 21, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Aaron David Miller. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris and Jan Ransom
title: 5 Takeaways From a Times Investigation of New York’s Social Safety Net
description: Homeless shelters, hospitals and specialized treatment teams have repeatedly failed to prevent homeless mentally ill people from committing acts of violence.
content: New York City’s social safety net has repeatedly failed to prevent mentally ill people from unraveling on the streets and committing random acts of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: A Fresh Look at Thai Food at Bangkok Supper Club
description: The chef Max Wittawat offers dishes both rustic and refined in an up-to-the-moment setting.
content: Max Wittawat was a pastry chef at Spot Dessert Bar for 13 years, and sometimes you can see the imprint of that work in the Thai food he serves now as the chef of Bangkok Supper Club, a new restaurant in the West Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: globalization
description: This word has appeared in 126 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word globalization has appeared in 126 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 22 in the Opinion essay “A Brief History of a Problematic Appetizer” by Ian Urbina:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Animals Meant for Adoption May Have Been Turned Into Reptile Food
description: The fate of more than 250 rabbits, guinea pigs and rats remains unknown more than three months after they were sent to a humane society in Arizona.
content: When the San Diego Humane Society in California shipped more than 300 rabbits, guinea pigs and rats to the Humane Society of Southern Arizona in Tucson over the summer, it believed that they would be adopted as pets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: This Creamy Baked Mac and Cheese Is a Thanksgiving Must Have
description: Before you ask: Yes, there’s Velveeta involved.
content: Hello! It is Tuesday afternoon, and the big feast is in T-minus 48 hours. Let’s get straight into it, shall we?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Comita
title: The Wild Beauty of Moss
description: The inconspicuous plant is now the unexpected star of many naturalistic arrangements.
content: GROWING UP IN Vermont’s Northeast Kingdom region, the floral designer Emily Thompson was fascinated by the velvety mosses that blanket the area’s forest floors and creep along its glacial boulders. “Moss is so fertile and delectable,” she says. “Each piece is its own little realm.” Since opening her namesake New York-based studio in 2009, she has often included the plant in her arrangements, from the fairyland gardens she created under the White House Christmas trees in 2011 to the moss-and-lichen-covered stones she deployed as centerpieces for a wedding at the New York Public Library’s main branch in 2021. “I like to see moss celebrated for its own sake,” she says, alluding to the behind-the-scenes role it’s historically played in floral design, covering the roots of potted orchids or chicken wire used to build sculptural installations. But that approach is changing as designers are increasingly placing moss in the spotlight, embracing it as a substitute for evergreens in holiday wreaths or draping swaths of it across mantels and tabletops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: The Long Shadow of Steve Jobs Looms Over the Turmoil at OpenAI
description: Sam Altman, the most prominent promoter of artificial intelligence, learned that it’s hard to be a visionary founder like the Apple legend.
content: Steve Jobs, driven by his genius and his gut, invented the iPhone and built Apple into the world’s most valuable company. He was uncompromising, larger than life and irreplaceable. His life was creating the future, which would be filled with devices controlled by their users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Is This the World’s Highest-Grossing Photograph?
description: “Girls in the Windows” wasn’t made by an art world giant, but people keep buying it. And buying it. And buying it.
content: Standing on a second-story fire escape, a photographer named Ormond Gigli is shouting instructions through a bullhorn. Forty models are posing in the window frames of brownstones across East 58th Street on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, a menagerie of colorful dresses and evening gowns. Two more women stand on the sidewalk, next to a silver Rolls-Royce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Selam Gebrekidan
title: Electronic Warfare Confounds Civilian Pilots, Far From Any Battlefield
description: Planes were built to trust GPS signals. Jamming and spoofing in the Middle East and Ukraine have diverted flights and caused inaccurate onboard alerts.
content: Electronic warfare in the Middle East and Ukraine is affecting air travel far from the battlefields, unnerving pilots and exposing an unintended consequence of a tactic that experts say will become more common.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: At BRICS Summit, Countries Diverge Slightly on Israel and War in Gaza
description: They called for the release of all civilians who are being illegally held captive, as well as a humanitarian truce that would lead to a cessation of hostilities.
content: The BRICS group of developing countries — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa — held a virtual summit on the war in Gaza on Tuesday, articulating divergent positions on the conflict that together reflected the reluctance of some nations outside the world’s largest industrialized democracies to fall in behind Washington’s support for Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Johnson Pays Trump Visit as He Faces Mounting Criticism from the Right
description: It was the speaker’s first trip to see the former president since he won his post, and it came as he faced anger from right-wing lawmakers for moving to fund the government.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson on Monday night visited former President Donald J. Trump at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida, according to a person familiar with the meeting, making his first pilgrimage to see the Republican presidential front-runner since his surprise elevation to the top post in the House last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Tiny Superhero
description: Kevin Christian and Andrea Carla Michaels have their fingers on the pulse of crosswords.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 21, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 21, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about sweltering heat at Taylor Swift’s concerts in Brazil misstated the title of a Taylor Swift song. It is “You Belong With Me,” not “You Belong to Me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Family Photos Have Never Looked So Chic
description: Thebe Magugu, the South African designer, takes memories to the most fashionable level.
content: Forget whipping out your phone to show off your family photos or tucking a loved one’s face into a locket around your neck. What if you could wear your favorite memories on your back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Ignore Trump? Democrats Now Want Him Plastered All Over the News.
description: The former president has been relatively quiet, out of the headlines and off mainstream social media. Democrats are hoping that more attention on him can help turn around President Biden’s fortunes.
content: When Donald J. Trump left the White House, Democrats didn’t want to hear another word from him. President Biden dismissed him as “the former guy.” A party-wide consensus held that he was best left ignored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The ‘Cease-Fire Now’ Imposture
description: It’s not a call for sparing innocent Palestinians. It’s a demand for Israel’s total surrender.
content: This has been updated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: Is Ireland Headed for a Merger?
description: Have demographics and Brexit made unification inevitable?
content: Before she died in 2013, Dolours Price, a Provisional Irish Republican Army guerrilla, started granting interviews. She described planting I.R.A. bombs and driving people to their executions, smuggling explosives and going on hunger strike in a British prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Conway, J. Michael Luttig and Barbara Comstock
title: The Trump Threat Is Growing. Lawyers Must Rise to Meet This Moment.
description: The legal profession has stood largely silent on assaults on America’s democracy. The situation will grow worse if Trump returns to the White House.
content: American democracy, the Constitution and the rule of law are the righteous causes of our times, and the nation’s legal profession is obligated to support them. But with the acquiescence of the larger conservative legal movement, these pillars of our system of governance are increasingly in peril. The dangers will only grow should Donald Trump be returned to the White House next November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: BBC Announces It Will Pause Popular Car Show ‘Top Gear’
description: The BBC decision to halt production of the car show came after a presenter, Andrew “Freddie” Flintoff, was seriously injured in a crash during filming last year.
content: The British car show “Top Gear,” one of the BBC’s most profitable and popular shows, will stop running after a presenter, Andrew “Freddie” Flintoff, was seriously injured in a crash during filming last year, the BBC said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Health Report Claims ‘Weight Reduction’ but Skimps on Specifics
description: The former president’s doctors have often offered hyperbolic or unverifiable claims in reports about his health.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump posted a fawning but vague health report from his doctor on Monday that declares that Mr. Trump’s health is “excellent” and that he has recently lost weight through an “improved diet” and “daily physical activity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Produce Company Recalls Fruit Amid Listeria Outbreak
description: One person has died and 10 people have been hospitalized across seven states: California, Colorado, Kansas, Illinois, Ohio, Michigan and Florida.
content: A California produce company has voluntarily recalled its whole peaches, plums and nectarines in connection with an outbreak of listeria that has led to one death and 10 hospitalizations since 2018, according to a food safety alert published Monday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘The Boy and the Heron’ Review: Hayao Miyazaki Has a Question for You
description: The anime filmmaker returns at 82 with the enigmatic tale of a boy growing up amid war and fear, much as the director did.
content: In 1944, when the future anime master Hayao Miyazaki was 3, his family fled Tokyo for the countryside, where they remained through his earliest schooling. Miyazaki’s father worked in a fighter plane factory, and young Hayao’s earliest memories, he’s said in interviews, involved war and fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: The Chaos at OpenAI, Explained
description: How fears over the future led to a tech-world coup.
content: If they had been the plot of a science fiction movie, or an episode of “Succession,” the events at OpenAI last weekend would have seemed a little over-the-top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Stella Tan, Carlos Prieto, Summer Thomad, Paige Cowett, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A Reporter’s Journey Into Gaza
description: New York Times journalists traveled with an Israeli military convoy to catch a rare glimpse of the wartime conditions in the enclave.
content: As the war against Hamas enters a seventh week, Israel finds itself under intense pressure to justify its actions in Gaza, including the raid of Al-Shifa Hospital, which it says is a center of Hamas activity. Hamas and hospital officials deny the accusation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Mucus-Covered Jellyfish Hint at Dangers of Deep-Sea Mining
description: Shipboard experiments suggested that sediment from the exploitation of metals in the ocean could be harmful to marine life.
content: A treasure trove of metal is hiding at the bottom of the ocean. Potato-size nodules of iron and manganese litter the seafloor, and metal-rich crusts cover underwater mountains and chimneys along hydrothermal vents. Deep-sea mining companies have set their sights on these minerals, aiming to use them in batteries and electronics. Environmentalists warn that the mining process and the plumes of sediment it would dump back into the sea could affect marine life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Robinson and Emily Holzknecht
title: Your Rewards Card Is Actually Bad for You, and for Everyone Else
description: Chasing credit card points is a game that everyone loses.
content: Earn 75,000 bonus miles! Double cash back! Free flights! Discounts galore!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Full Exposure? Four Solo Shows Ponder the Art of True Nature.
description: Lameece Issaq’s “A Good Day to Me Not to You” strives for intimacy, but that is not necessarily the aim of works by Alexandra Tatarsky, Milo Cramer and Ikechukwu Ufomadu.
content: Two years of post-shutdown theater has brought to New York stages a slew of solo performers wrestling with subjects like grief, death and the apocalypse — and those are just the comedies. Solo shows are inexpensive to produce and relatively low-lift endeavors for an industry still on shaky ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: How the Voting Rights Act, Newly Challenged, Has Long Been Under Attack
description: A federal ruling this week was only the latest in decades of legal challenges to a law that has shored up Black Americans’ political power.
content: The Voting Rights Act, a landmark law that has for decades protected Black Americans from attempts to erode their political power, was dealt one of its most significant challenges this week when a federal appeals court moved to strike down a crucial part of the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Officials Thought Rates Could Rise More if Inflation Stayed Stubborn
description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s early November meeting suggested another rate increase remained possible, but officials were in no hurry.
content: Federal Reserve officials are contemplating whether they will need to raise interest rates again to cool the economy and ensure that rapid inflation will fully fade, and minutes from their meeting earlier this month laid out the contours of that debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Thanksgiving Dinner
description: What’s your favorite holiday dish?
content: Cranberry sauce? Mac and cheese? Stuffing? How about the iconic holiday bird itself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Wish’ Review: The Sorcerer’s Disgruntled Apprentice
description: Celebrating Disney’s 100th anniversary, the animated musical starring Ariana DeBose and Chris Pine, is a reminder of the studio’s vaunted past.
content: In October, The Walt Disney Company hailed its 100th birthday, marking the centennial of the day the brothers Walt and Roy Disney founded a studio to produce silent one-reel comedies. (Mickey Mouse wouldn’t be born until 1928, so expect another shindig in five years.) As a party favor, the company gives us “Wish,” an amiable, young-skewing trifle that casually retcons Disney’s entire back catalog into a single magical universe. Peter Pan, Mary Poppins, talking mice, autonomous flying scissors, Cinderella’s fairy godmother — heck, even Disneyland’s nightly fireworks — can hereafter trace their roots to this animated prequel set on a Mediterranean island ruled by a silver-pompadoured sorcerer named King Magnifico (the voice of Chris Pine) and his wife, Queen Amaya (Angelique Cabral).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel and Hamas Said They Are Close to a Hostage Deal
description: Also, a new blow to the crypto world. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: In a news conference this evening, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called for his government to back a deal with Hamas that would pause combat for several days and free some of the captives held by Hamas in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A Crisis at Gaza’s Hospitals, and More
description: Plus, a federal court moves to weaken the Voting Rights Act and cities stress over driverless taxis.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily LaBarge
title: What Is Photography? (No Need to Answer That.)
description: Two exhibitions by Japanese artists raise deep questions about the medium, and — refreshingly — leave them hanging.
content: There’s more than one answer to the question “What is photography?,” and this fall in London, there is a dazzling array of possibilities on show in retrospectives of the Japanese artists Hiroshi Sugimoto and Daido Moriyama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘It’s a Rom-Com Opening, Baby!’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood. “Your total is $20.69,” announces the cashier at my register. Seconds later, the cashier at the next register over says to a male customer, “Your total is $20.69.” Wait, what? The staff whoops. Someone says, “No way!” He and I grin sloppily in the sudden spotlight, paired so arbitrarily by groceries. Bystander: “It’s a rom-com opening, baby!” The other $20.69 meets my eyes, testing gently for truth in that idea. For a moment, I entertain another universe — one where I’m not gay — and smile wide. Then I say, “Good night.” — Zoe Marie Bel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Tallerico
title: Minnesota Nice: The History of ‘Fargo’
description: The new season of FX’s Coenverse crime drama goes back to the basics. Here is a look at the various chapters that came before it.
content: The Emmy-winning FX limited series “Fargo” returns Tuesday with a new season, its fifth, that stars Juno Temple and Jon Hamm and goes back to the basics: Minnesota cops, North Dakota bad guys and plenty of snow-covered landscapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City May Pay You to Build a ‘Granny Flat’ in Your Backyard
description: Fifteen New Yorkers living in single-family homes could get up to nearly $400,000 to build an extra apartment on their properties.
content: To address the big problem of New York’s housing crisis, the city is trying something small: payments to homeowners to build apartments in their garages and attics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Senate Is Getting Less Democratic by the Minute
description: As the country has grown larger and more diverse, the disparities have grown greater and more perverse.
content: Democrats and the independents who caucus with them will be playing defense in 23 of the 34 Senate seats on the ballot in the 2024 congressional elections. Four of the 23 are in swing states that Joe Biden won narrowly in 2020. Three are in states that Donald Trump won in both 2016 and 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: As A.I.-Controlled Killer Drones Become Reality, Nations Debate Limits
description: Worried about the risks of robot warfare, some countries want new legal constraints, but the U.S. and other major powers are resistant.
content: It seems like something out of science fiction: swarms of killer robots that hunt down targets on their own and are capable of flying in for the kill without any human signing off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: ‘Who’s That Wonderful Girl? Could She Be Any Cuter?’
description: She’s Mona, the puppet heroine of “Nanalan’,” an old Canadian children’s show that has found a new audience on TikTok.
content: “Nanalan’” hasn’t been on TV in years, but it’s the hottest show on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Asylum in America, by the Numbers
description: A migration crisis is overwhelming government resources as thousands of people come to the United States looking for safety every day.
content: Under President Biden, the Border Patrol has arrested more people for illegally crossing the southern border into the country than in any other period since the government started keeping count in 1960.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Tripp Mickle and Mike Isaac
title: Before Altman’s Ouster, OpenAI’s Board Was Divided and Feuding
description: Sam Altman attacked a member over a research paper that discussed the company, while directors disagreed about who should fill board vacancies open for months.
content: Before Sam Altman was ousted from OpenAI last week, he and the company’s board of directors had been bickering for more than a year. The tension got worse as OpenAI became a mainstream name thanks to its popular ChatGPT chatbot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Conditions for women and children in Gaza.
content: The streets were empty. The ambulance couldn’t come for more than half an hour, and the hospital’s maternity ward no longer functioned. The only sounds were the noises of planes and shelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Peter Tarnoff Dies at 86; Diplomat Helped Plot ‘Argo’ Escape from Iran
description: A consummate man behind the scenes, he held top posts under Carter and Clinton, and in between ran the Council on Foreign Relations.
content: Peter Tarnoff, a seasoned diplomat whose work behind the scenes for presidents Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton included establishing a secret channel to Fidel Castro and helping arrange the escape of six U.S. Embassy officials from Iran, an escapade later depicted in the 2012 movie “Argo,” died on Nov. 1 at his home in San Francisco. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
title: X Sues Media Matters Over Research on Ads Next to Antisemitic Posts
description: X asked a federal court to order the advocacy group to take down its findings, accusing it of “manipulating the algorithms.”
content: X, the social media service formerly known as Twitter, sued Media Matters in federal court on Monday after the advocacy organization published research showing that ads on X appeared next to antisemitic content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Figure Eight Takes a Southern Approach to Chinese Cuisine
description: Radio Star conjures the 1940s, Yono Sushi arrives at Moynihan Train Hall and more restaurant news.
content: Emmeline Zhao, an owner of Silver Apricot, where Chinese food is interpreted through a new American lens, has created her own competition. Next door to Silver Apricot she has opened this new spot, in the brick-walled premises that previously housed the beloved Pearl Oyster Bar. “So far the two restaurants seem to reinforce each other,” Ms. Zhao said. “We’ve had people come here for a drink and a snack, because Silver Apricot doesn’t have a bar, and then have dinner at Silver Apricot.” The Chinese American approach, intended to express something of the immigrant experience, is given a narrower frame than at Silver Apricot, with emphasis on the Southern Atlantic region where Ms. Zhao, a North Carolina native, was raised. So you’ll find turnip tots with lap cheong mayo and shrimp ketchup; shrimp cocktail with Chinese horseradish; Hong Shao collard greens with pork belly and Thai chile; grilled branzino; soy-poached chicken with collard greens and crispy hoppin’ John; and hot fried skate with chile crisp, buttermilk ranch dressing and sesame biscuits. Like its sibling, the tables are not set with chopsticks but they can be requested. The executive chef, Calvin Hwang, who grew up in New Jersey, worked at Crown Shy and Saga. The pastry chef, Janice Sung, was at Saga and One White Street; among her creations is a banana custard pie seasoned with Chinese five-spice. The restaurant has three areas. At the entrance is a 12-seat bar with a standing rail and a jazzy dragon splashed across the wall. The main dining room is done mostly in blue and white in homage, Ms. Zhao said, to Pearl Oyster Bar’s seafood. And there’s an intimate semiprivate room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Alexander
title: In the Middle of a War With No End in Sight
description: In “November 1942,” Peter Englund pieces together a month in the Second World War with the diaries and memoirs of the people who survived it.
content: “This is a book about November 1942,” the Swedish economist and historian Peter Englund explains in his introductory note to the reader, “the month that marked the turning point of the Second World War.” November 1942 was the month that brought the Allies hard-fought victories in North Africa and inspired Churchill to say that the war had reached “the end of the beginning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Who are the Palestinian prisoners who could be released in a hostage deal?
description: Negotiations have centered on releasing women and children held in Israel.
content: Negotiations around the release of Israeli women and children held hostage in Gaza have centered on an exchange for Palestinian women and minors held in Israeli prisons. The size of that group has grown quickly during the six weeks of war and upheaval since the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel, according to a Palestinian prisoners’ rights group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Did a Cafe’s Pro-Israel Stance Cause a Staff Revolt? It’s Complicated.
description: When the owner of a New York City coffee shop said his workers had quit over his support of Israel, customers and Instagram influencers flocked to it.
content: For several days this month, New Yorkers stood in a line that snaked down Lexington Avenue and around the corner of East 71st Street, waiting up to 90 minutes to order a drink at Caffè Aronne. Members of the city’s Jewish community, spurred by messages on social media, turned out in droves to support a coffee shop owner who had said that his employees had walked out to protest the company’s support for Israel during the war with Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Mayor Adams Said He Will Cut the N.Y.P.D. Does He Mean It?
description: In the Police Department, the rank and file is hearing rumors of buyouts and demotions, but many see the mayor’s plan to shrink the department as a political tactic.
content: Soon after Mayor Eric Adams said he would enact a hiring freeze at the Police Department, the alarming texts began to circulate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: We Did an Experiment to See How Much Democracy and Abortion Matter to Voters
description: Yes, the economy is important, but we found that election subversion attempts appear to matter more to voters than polling suggests.
content: Do abortion and democracy matter to voters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Palantir Wins Major U.K. Health Contract Despite Criticism
description: The Peter Thiel-owned company overcame opposition from activists, doctors and lawmakers to sign a lucrative deal with England’s National Health Service.
content: Palantir, the software company founded by the billionaire Peter Thiel, won a major contract in Britain on Tuesday to help overhaul the technology system of the country’s state-run health service, overcoming concerns that a firm known for its military-related work in the United States would secure such a sensitive role involving patient data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: ‘High on the Hog’ Returns With Stories of Food, Resistance and Legacy
description: In Season 2 of the Netflix series, Stephen Satterfield explores generational conversations among Black people through food.
content: When Georgianne Thomas, 80, an author and adjunct professor of humanities at Clark Atlanta University, pushes aside the yellow bracelet adorning her wrist to reveal a burn mark, the table of people she’s dining with are stunned. The mark, decades old but still visible, was left by a Ku Klux Klan member putting out a cigarette on her arm during a protest in Atlanta when she was a 17-year-old freshman at Spelman College in 1960.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Freezes Government Spending as Budget Crisis Deepens
description: The government, scrambling to fill a budget gap in the wake of a court ruling, said it would halt future spending commitments.
content: The German government said on Tuesday it would immediately halt all new spending as it grappled with how to plug a gap of tens of billions of euros following a court ruling that has triggered a budget crisis in Europe’s largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy and Brooks Barnes
title: Susan Sarandon Dropped by Talent Agency After Remarks on Gaza War
description: Sarandon, the Academy Award-winning actress, was dropped by United Talent Agency. Separately, Melissa Barrera lost her role in the “Scream” movies for Instagram posts about Israel.
content: Two actresses, one an Academy Award-winning veteran and the other a relative newcomer, have been dropped by Hollywood companies after comments they separately made about the Israel-Hamas war drew criticism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Federal Judge Rules Undated Mail-In Ballots in Pennsylvania Must Be Counted
description: The judge said that a state law requiring voters to date the return envelope violated the voting protections of the Civil Rights Act.
content: A federal judge in Pennsylvania ruled on Monday that mail-in ballots that are received on time but are undated should be counted, arguing that a state law rejecting such votes violates the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Users of Venmo, Cash App and Other Digital Wallets Get a Tax Reprieve
description: The Biden administration has faced backlash from small-business owners who called the new I.R.S. reporting requirements confusing and onerous.
content: For the second time in a year, the Internal Revenue Service is delaying enforcement of a contentious tax policy that would require users of digital wallets and e-commerce platforms to start reporting small transactions to the tax collection agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Omicron, Now 2 Years Old, Is Not Done With Us Yet
description: The dominant variant of the coronavirus has proved to be not only staggeringly infectious, but an evolutionary marvel.
content: By November 2021, nearly two years after the coronavirus emerged in Wuhan and spread across the world, the surprises seemed to be over. More than four billion people had been vaccinated against the virus, and five million had died. Two new variants, known as Alpha and Delta, had surged and then ebbed. As Thanksgiving approached, many Americans were planning to resume traveling for the holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Genie’ Review: Wishing for a Better Movie
description: Melissa McCarthy grants unlimited magical requests in this holiday fantasy film.
content: In conventional, old-fashioned stories about wish-granting genies, the number of wishes is limited to three, the better to deliver a solid punchline or useful lesson. In our consumerist and content-crazy times, a mere three wishes won’t do. “Genie,” a new film directed by Sam Boyd, stars Melissa McCarthy as Flora, a genie unleashed by an overworked dad as he massages an old jewel box he tried to pass off as a birthday present for the daughter whose celebration he missed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: ‘I Think We’re Heading Toward the Best World Ever’: An Interview With Sam Altman
description: We spoke to the OpenAI founder just two days before he was ousted by his company’s board in a surprise coup. To him, the future seemed bright.
content: When Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, strolled into The Times’s San Francisco bureau last Wednesday morning, he looked carefree and relaxed — a happy mogul in an orange hoodie, riding a wave of success atop one of Silicon Valley’s hottest companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer
title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Neck Pain
description: Neck pain is common, but working on your posture and strengthening your spine can help.
content: Experts estimate that up to 80 percent of people will experience some form of neck pain in their lives, and as much as half of Americans will suffer from it this year alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Carlton Pearson, Pastor Deemed a Heretic for Denying Hell, Dies at 70
description: He led a popular religious revival and a megachurch, but his peers and congregation abandoned him once he questioned core doctrine and advocated gay rights.
content: Bishop Carlton D. Pearson, an evangelical pastor who was deserted by his large congregation after declaring that hell does not exist and advocating gay rights — and whose story was told in a 2018 Netflix movie — died on Sunday in Tulsa, Okla. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Wisconsin Court Hears Case That Could Upend State Politics
description: A challenge to district maps that have locked in Republican control of the Legislature was argued on Tuesday before a State Supreme Court with a new 4-to-3 liberal majority.
content: The deep ideological split on the Wisconsin Supreme Court was clear on Tuesday as the court heard arguments in a case with the potential to upend political power in the state: a challenge to the state’s legislative district maps, regarded as among the most aggressively gerrymandered in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Navy Plane Misses Runway in Hawaii and Ends Up in Water With 9 Aboard
description: None of the crew members were injured when a maritime patrol aircraft overshot a runway at Marine Corps Base Hawaii, the military said.
content: A United States Navy maritime patrol aircraft overshot a runway after landing at a Marine Corps base in Hawaii on Monday and ended up in nearby waters, the Marine Corps said. The nine crew members on board all escaped uninjured.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Set the Table With This Thanksgiving Playlist
description: The Highwomen, James Brown and yes, the Cranberries.
content: Thanksgiving is nearly upon us, so today’s playlist is all about gratitude, family, and … food. Heaps and heaps of steaming, delicious food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Strikes Iranian-Linked Facilities in Iraq
description: The airstrikes followed an earlier exchange in which a U.S. gunship spotted and fired on militants after they launched missiles at Al Asad Air Base.
content: The United States conducted a new round of airstrikes — the second in roughly a day — in Iraq early Wednesday, destroying two facilities used by Iranian proxies that had been targeting American and coalition troops, U.S. military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: She Writes Storybook Endings. Of Course She Got the House.
description: A Hallmark Channel screenwriter shares her secret for prevailing over all-cash offers: “Maybe what I do for a living gave me a little bit of an advantage.”
content: The house, a traditional 1940s white stucco ranch, felt just right to Nina Weinman. It was in central Los Angeles, where she and her husband wanted to live, and it was in their price range.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Ford Resumes Work on E.V. Battery Plant in Michigan, at Reduced Scale
description: A battery plant in Michigan will be smaller than planned, Ford said, citing slower E.V. demand than expected, as well as labor costs.
content: Ford Motor said Tuesday that it was resuming work on an electric vehicle battery plant in Michigan but significantly scaling back its plans in part because of slow E.V. adoption in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Your Next 10 Steps After Watching the New ‘Napoleon’ Film
description: If you want to read his biography, or even see his horse, you can.
content: With the new Ridley Scott film “Napoleon,” starring Joaquin Phoenix and Vanessa Kirby, hitting theaters this week, General Bonaparte is having a cultural moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: DeSantis Picks Up Key Endorsement From Iowa Religious Leader
description: The endorsement by Bob Vander Plaats was long expected, but comes as Gov. Ron DeSantis has tried to build momentum heading into the Iowa caucuses in January.
content: The influential Iowa evangelical leader Bob Vander Plaats endorsed Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday, the second major endorsement Mr. DeSantis has picked up this month in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
title: Pan-Arab News Network Says Israeli Strike Killed Two of Its Journalists
description: The Lebanese military and Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister blamed Israel for the attack as the Israeli military said the episode was under review.
content: As cross-border clashes intensified between Israel and the armed group Hezbollah, three people, including two television journalists, were killed in an Israeli strike on Tuesday in southern Lebanon, Lebanese officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Jeff Zucker Nears Major Deal to Re-enter the News Business
description: The veteran TV executive is poised to take control of two prominent British news outlets, The Daily Telegraph and The Spectator, and may expand them into America.
content: Jeff Zucker: Tory media titan?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Romy Gill
title: Tea, a Train and an Epic Sunrise at a Summer Retreat of the Raj
description: Darjeeling, in the Himalayan foothills, is famous for its tea, its elevated railroad and the view of dawn breaking over Mt. Everest. A writer fulfilled a childhood dream of visiting.
content: Ever since I was a little girl I’d dreamed of going to Darjeeling. My imagination was captivated by this town nestled in the foothills of the Himalayas in the Indian state of West Bengal. Surrounded by lush, terraced tea gardens that extend across rolling hills, with the majestic snow-capped mountains behind them, Darjeeling is one of India’s most stunning hill stations, known as the Queen of the Mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Neighborhood That’s Shedding Offices for Housing
description: The financial district is attracting residents who like the charm of the narrow streets and can live with the neighborhood’s lack of sunlight.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at the transformation of the financial district, as office buildings are being turned into apartments. We’ll also look at why the Police Department is spending $500 million on new radios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azadeh Moaveni
title: Before Hillary Clinton, There Was Rosalynn Carter
description: She was the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt. Why have her efforts been so overlooked?
content: When Americans look back and take stock of their most impressive first ladies, they rarely think of Rosalynn Carter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Music Licensing Giant BMI Sells to Private Equity Firm
description: Broadcast Music Inc., one of the major performing rights organizations in the United States, collected $1.57 billion and distributed $1.47 billion for its 2022 fiscal year.
content: BMI, the giant music licensing agency that represents hundreds of thousands of songwriters, including Taylor Swift, Dolly Parton, Kendrick Lamar and Lady Gaga, has agreed to sell itself to New Mountain Capital, a private equity firm, the organization announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: For ‘Napoleon,’ Finishing the Hats
description: Inside the creation of one emperor’s famous headwear, as worn by Joaquin Phoenix in Ridley Scott’s film.
content: When the costume designer David Crossman, who specializes in military wear, first knew he would be working on “Napoleon” (in theaters Wednesday), Ridley Scott’s epic starring Joaquin Phoenix, he had a “mini panic” about the hats. It wasn’t that he would have to be recreating Napoleon Bonaparte’s famous headgear, the kind for which collectors pay dearly (one just sold for $2.1 million). It was that he would be doing it with certain limitations. Phoenix is vegan and doesn’t wear any animal products, which meant that Crossman couldn’t use wool felt. “Immediately, I just felt it’s going to be a problem of what to make the iconic hat out of because it’s all going to be about the hat,” Crossman said in a video call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Does A.I. Have an Inherent Governance Problem?
description: OpenAI’s intricate structure, which contributed to the ouster of Sam Altman, is complex by design.
content: The future of OpenAI, whose ChatGPT kick-started an arms race in artificial intelligence, has grown even cloudier. A majority of its workers called on its board to resign after ousting Sam Altman as C.E.O. over how fast to commercialize its technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine’s Children With Special Needs Suffer the ‘Huge Pressure’ of War
description: Children with conditions like ADHD and autism have been particularly affected by the traumas and uncertainties of the war and the disruptions to daily life, families and experts say.
content: Maksym, 13, needs a life of stability and routines, but almost two years of war in Ukraine have given him anything but that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Sunak’s Dilemma: When to Hold an Election He’ll Probably Lose
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is 20 percentage points behind in opinion polls. But history suggests the timing of a vote might make a difference.
content: No question in British politics will be more regularly asked, and reliably brushed aside, over the next few months than when Prime Minister Rishi Sunak plans to call the country’s next general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: A Gaza Hostage Deal Appears Close
description: Plus Binance’s founder pleads guilty.
content: Israel and Hamas appeared to be edging close to a deal that would allow the release of some of the 240 captives held in Gaza in exchange for some Palestinian prisoners held by Israel. The exchange would take place during what would be a brief pause in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Nadelson
title: The Luncheonette Serving New York’s Best Egg Creams
description: The owners of Lexington Candy Shop have, for over 98 years, refined their recipe and still make their syrups from scratch.
content: When I was growing up in Greenwich Village, my mother would take me uptown — an adventure in itself — to my pediatrician on Park Avenue. Afterward, we went to the Lexington Candy Shop on the corner of Lexington Avenue and 83rd Street for lunch (candy, deceptively, was in short supply). I’d have a chocolate egg cream and grilled cheese; she’d order a toasted corn muffin and black coffee. A few weeks ago, sitting in the forest green Naugahyde booth at the back of the restaurant, I thought of her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Judge Modifies a Trump Co-Defendant’s Bail Conditions
description: Prosecutors say the defendant, Harrison Floyd, has been intimidating potential witnesses in the racketeering case with his social media posts.
content: In a fiery courtroom presentation, the prosecutor overseeing the Georgia racketeering case against former President Donald J. Trump argued on Tuesday that one of Mr. Trump’s co-defendants had intimidated potential witnesses on social media and should be sent to jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Angwin
title: The OpenAI Coup Is Great for Microsoft. What Does It Mean for Us?
description: The OpenAI fracas most likely cements control of one of the most powerful and promising technologies on the planet under one of this country’s tech titans.
content: There was the coup that hit the headlines: the OpenAI board’s abrupt ousting of its co-founder and chief executive, Sam Altman. Now we are on the verge of a second, even more critical coup, one that cements control of one of the most powerful and promising technologies on the planet under one of this country’s tech titans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: Mayhem at OpenAI + Our Interview With Sam Altman
description: Tech’s wildest weekend.
content: Read the transcript from our interview with Sam Altman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Leo’ Review: A Cold-Blooded Creature With a Heart of Gold
description: Adam Sandler plays a gruff old lizard who dishes out advice to fifth graders in this animated comedy.
content: Adam Sandler stars in “Leo” as a grumpy lizard who has spent his entire life in the terrarium of a fifth-grade classroom. He’s been joined by a turtle named Squirtle (Bill Burr), and the two are mostly content to stare out the glass, year after year, commenting like Statler and Waldorf on the various tween archetypes that show up on the first day of school: the motormouth, the class clown, the kid with helicopter parents who’s allergic to everything. But the bubble bursts for Sandler’s Leo when he realizes that he’s approaching 75 — the average life span for his species — and has hardly gotten to live out his dreams as a free lizard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Remembers Popular Uprising That Foreshadowed War
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky hailed the so-called Maidan revolution, which toppled a pro-Russia leader 10 years ago, as the “first victory” in a long struggle against Moscow.
content: A war-battered Ukraine on Tuesday commemorated the 10th anniversary of the so-called Maidan revolution, the popular uprising that toppled a pro-Russia president, showcased the nation’s embrace of European values and foreshadowed the current conflict with Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Whittaker and Thomas Fuller
title: Two Years With America’s Elite Firefighters
description: Hotshot fire crews work on the front lines of the biggest wildfires in the American West. We rode along with them.
content: Early this summer, while many Americans were gathering for Fourth of July barbecues, the Tallac Hotshots were in triple-digit heat in Arizona, fighting a wildfire for 14 straight days and sleeping on the ground next to their trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘Gardens of Anuncia’ Review: The Broadway Star and the Women Who Molded Her
description: Michael John LaChiusa’s beautifully sung tribute to sisterly admiration, starring Priscilla Lopez, was inspired by the early life of the show’s director, Graciela Daniele.
content: At the heart of “The Gardens of Anuncia,” Michael John LaChiusa’s sweet reverie of a musical, is a respect and recognition for the renowned Broadway choreographer Graciela Daniele, a longtime friend and collaborator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: David Letterman Ends Conspicuous Absence From ‘The Late Show’
description: The comedian has visited many shows in the past eight years — but not, until Monday night, the one he hosted for 22 years.
content: It started much like the way it ended for David Letterman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Mike Ives
title: What Plants Will Survive in Your Garden? This Map Plans for a Warmer U.S.
description: About half of the country moved into a slightly warmer zone in the Agriculture Department’s new “plant hardiness” map, an important guide for gardeners. Climate change may be a factor.
content: Jason Reeves has been using the lantana, a flowering shrub, as a perennial in garden beds for the past few years. That was not the case a decade ago, when the plant would have died in the Tennessee winters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Californians Celebrate Thanksgiving
description: With outdoor feasts, sourdough stuffing and more.
content: It’s almost Thanksgiving, a holiday that in much of the country may evoke images of rustling autumn leaves and hands warmed by the fireplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: The Rules for Thanksgiving Wine
description: How many bottles to buy and more holiday advice from our wine critic.
content: How many bottles to buy and more holiday advice from our wine critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 100 Notable Books of 2023
description: Here are the year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, chosen by the staff of The New York Times Book Review.
content: Here are the year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, chosen by the staff of The New York Times Book Review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Reston, Margie Omero and Adrian J. Rivera
title: Dwayne ‘The Rock’ Johnson? Ocasio-Cortez? Mark Cuban? 12 Democrats on the Leaders We Need.
description: The group discusses what the Democratic Party means to them, its current strategy and its future after Biden.
content: The group discusses what the Democratic Party means to them, its current strategy and its future after Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republican Presidential Candidates on Matters of Democracy
description: As the Republican presidential candidates campaign under the shadow of a front-runner facing dozens of felony charges, The New York Times examined their stances on 12 key issues.
content: As the Republican presidential candidates campaign under the shadow of a front-runner facing dozens of felony charges, The New York Times examined their stances on 12 key issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Collins, Raúl Vilchis and Olivia Bensimon
title: Making a Home and Avoiding Deportation in New York City
description: More than 200,000 migrants have come to New York in the last 18 months. Five of them told us how they have found shelter, earned money and looked for legal ways to stay here.
content: More than 200,000 migrants have come to New York in the last 18 months. Five of them told us how they have found shelter, earned money and looked for legal ways to stay here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Indonesian Hospital Patients Transported to Nasser Hospital
description: Injured patients, including children, were moved by bus from one Gaza hospital to another on Monday.
content: Injured patients, including children, were moved by bus from one Gaza hospital to another on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Robinson and Emily Holzknecht
title: Your Rewards Card Is Actually Bad for You, and for Everyone Else
description: Chasing credit card points is a game where everyone loses.
content: Chasing credit card points is a game where everyone loses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Blumenfeld, Carmit Hoomash, Alexandra Eaton and Meg Felling
title: Israeli Teen Hopes Her Cousins Will Be Released Soon by Hamas
description: Sheffa Phillips-Bahat has two young cousins who were taken hostage from their home at Kibbutz Nir Oz. More than a month after they were kidnapped, she “can’t think of anything but getting the hostages back.”
content: Sheffa Phillips-Bahat has two young cousins who were taken hostage from their home at Kibbutz Nir Oz. More than a month after they were kidnapped, she “can’t think of anything but getting the hostages back.”
source.name: The New York Times
